byline.contributor: Fernanda Santos reported from Phoenix, and Motoko Rich from New York.
byline.original: By FERNANDA SANTOS and MOTOKO RICH

abstract: State funding for public schools, which was badly affected by 2008 recession, remains down 3.6 percent across country even as most state revenues have rebounded; experts say politics and policies play as great a role in reduced school funding as state economics; education in Arizona has been particularly hard hit by targeted cuts and voter refusal to raise taxes.
lead_paragraph: Arizona has been crippled by several years of targeted cuts at the state level and voters’ repeated refusals to raise property taxes to offset shortfalls.

headline.main: Recession, Politics and Policy Stretch Arizona School Budgets
headline.print_headline: School Funding Failing to Make Up for Recession
